title: Workshop 3–Overview
text:
Preface
These are materials for the workshop sessions on pandemic management and infectious disease control, presented as part of BM424 at the University of Strathclyde (SIPBS) in AY 2024-25.
Please use the menu on the left to find the briefing packet for your group. Group lists, and other workshop materials, are posted on the module MyPlace page.
Please report any issues or any broken links to Dr. Feeney.

title: Workshop 3–Overview
text:
0.1 Overview of workshop 3
In this workshop, you will work in groups to solve a scenario where a city has encountered a pandemic outbreak of disease. You will need to agree, as a group, on the actions you wish to take to limit the spread of the disease and mitigate the effects of the pandemic.
In the next workshop, you will be able to see what effect(s) your actions have had and further decide on the course(s) of action that your city should take.

0.1.1 Roles and Responsibilities






Tip



As a group, you should decide who will be responsible for which task(s) and how to allocate the work fairly. One possible way to divide the workload amongst your group is by choosing/allocating roles based on subject specialism, as outlined below. However, it is up to your group to decide on the best way to divide the work and a democratic process for making decisions.


Each member of your group will play one of the following roles as you attempt to tackle the disease outbreak and save your city:

Provost (head of the city council)
Representative from a national public health org. (Public Health Scotland)
Epidemiologist (on secondment from Public Health Scotland)
Director of the city’s main hospital
City planner/civil servant
Microbiologist (working in one of the NHS Scotland clinical labs)
Public communications expert (past and current sci comm campaigns)
Doctor at a major surgery
Epidemiologist from the local university wiht relevant expertise



0.1.2 Emergency Pandemic Response Team Meeting
You must work together, using the information that has been provided for you in the attached information packets, and decide what action(s) should be taken to control the outbreak currently plaguing your city.






Tip



Your actions should be evidence-based – use the peer-reviewed literature to decide on measures that will stop the pandemic in your scenario. What public health measures have previously been shown to work to contain similar outbreaks?




0.1.3 Submit committee decisions
You should submit 3-5 specific actions that your city will take to try to control the pandemic, using the workshop 3 pro forma (available on MyPlace). Submit this by noon, Friday March 7th, via the submission link on MyPlace. (Only one member in each group needs to submit the pro forma - you should decide among yourselves who will do this.)






Tip



Your action points may include directives to gather more information (e.g., contact tracing of current cases, microbiological testing of food/water, etc.), or specific directives (e.g. public health measures, non-pharmaceutical interventions, etc.). Use the data/expertise of all group members. Be clear, concise, and specific.

title: 2  Group A Main Page
text:
Pandemic OutbreakInverkeldLegionella pneumophilaPublic Opinion: News and E-mailsData Collected for the Pandemic Response Committee MeetingCity and Hospital Pandemic Planning ResourcesOther useful resources/links



Inverkeld Express

Breaking News
Fears Over Possible Outbreak of Legionellosis in Inverkeld
24 February, 2025
Anxiety is rising in Inverkeld as health officials investigate a potential outbreak of Legionellosis, raising alarm bells across the region. Though yet to be formally confirmed as a pandemic, suspicions have intensified following a recent stunning surge in patients presenting with symptoms indicative of Legionellosis.
Legionellosis is caused by Legionella pneumophila. It is typically transmitted through the inhalation of contaminated water droplets, such as those from air conditioning systems or hot tubs. Symptoms include fever, chills, cough, muscle aches, and headaches. Residents of Inverkeld experiencing any of these symptoms are advised to contact their GP or dial 111 for health advice.
In a press release, the director of the Queen Rose in Inverkeld noted a troubling uptick in individuals reporting symptoms consistent with those associated with Legionellosis. Concerns were first raised when the local GPs began reporting an unusual increase in patients with symptoms of Legionellosis. While investigations are still ongoing, the possibility of a pandemic outbreak hovers, prompting concern from health agencies.
In response to the expanding concerns, health officials have instigated several precautionary measures, and Inverkeld have convened an Emergency Pandemic Response Team, which will be meeting on 2025-02-28 and attempting to find solutions that will stop the spread of the pandemic in Inverkeld.
The First Minister assured residents that authorities are leaving exploring every avenue in their efforts to safeguard public health, and furthermore urged residents to remain vigilant and cooperate with health directives from the Inverkeld City Council. A statement released by the First Minister’s office read: “Despite the lack of confirmation regarding an outbreak, we are treating this matter with the utmost gravity.”
The people in Inverkeld have already begun to dread the possibility of a pandemic; potential consequences such as school closures, economic repercussions, and strain on healthcare resources, have sparked apprehension among residents, underscoring the need for swift and decisive action.
Contact Information for Further Updates:

More information will be posted on the Inverkeld website as the situation develops: https://www.InverkeldCouncil.co.uk
The Inverkeld Emergency Pandemic Response Team can be contacted on +44 01224 3756 6106 or at pandemic_response@Inverkeld.co.uk

About the Author:
Judy Her is a health correspondent at the Inverkeld Express, specializing in public health and safety issues.She can be contacted at jh4761@InverkeldExpress.com.







The Inverkeld city centre


Inverkeld was granted city status in 1886. Located near Castle Dunrobin, Inverkeld is noted for its annual folk festival featuring traditional music and dance. Major industries in the city include chemicals, automotive, and agriculture.
Inverkeld is well-served by public transport: there are 3 bus companies operating routes that cover the city and outlying areas, and road links to other major cities (the A40 to Ayr and the the A32 to Aberdeen.) Inverkeld is further connected to regional towns and villages by rail services from the Inverkeld railway station. Inverkeld is also served by Inverkeld Airport, which is 2 miles from the city centre and which offers daily flights to Munich, Madrid, and Bilbao.
Notable buildings in the city include Inverkeld Castle, Inverkeld Cathedral, and Hawthorn Abbey. Inverkeld also has several museums and art galleries and a riverfront promenade. The Inverkeld jazz festival is held annually in August, and tourists also flock to Inverkeld to take wildlife watching tours in autumn. Inverkeld is also noted as a hub of local arts and culture, with Riverbend Hall and Crawford Comedy Club drawing in crowds for performances from local and international artists. The city is renowned for sports, with the Lions and Falcons teams representing the city for field hockey and cricket, respectively.
Some of the key Inverkeld features are summarized in the list below.

Public Facilities/Community Amenities

Schools:

9 primary schools
3 secondary schools

Hospital: the Queen Rose

Refer to the “Data” tab for information about the city demographics, voting and polling data, and more information about the hospital.

Emails
Your committee has recently received a great deal of correspondence regarding the pandemic in Inverkeld. A representative sample of these e-mails is shown below.






Email #1





From: d.pereyra@gmail.com To: pandemic_response@Inverkeld.co.uk  Cc:  Subject: This Terrible Pandemic  Date: 29 January 2025 14:32
Dear Pandemic Committee,
I am devastated to hear about this new pandemic in Inverkeld. There seems to be no end to the suffering that pandemics inflict on our city in these days.
I hope very much that your office is going to do something about tragedy at once.
Yours truly, David Pereyra









Email #2





From: el-yacoub5684@aol.com  To: pandemic_response@Inverkeld.co.uk  Cc: BusinessSupport@Inverkeld.co.uk  Subject: Pandemic Tragedy for Businesses  Date: 29 January 2025 6:39 
Dear Pandemic Response Committee,
This new pandemic in Inverkeld has the potential to obliterate our businesses. I run a used bookstore on the high street and had to shut our doors and lost huge amounts of money due to COVID. Similarly, my neighbour Daniel, who runs Candy Corner, had to close because of all the draconian lockdowns.
I hope you realise how costly the last pandemic was for millions of people across the country, and that we can’t afford another one.
I pray that your office is going to do something about this state of affairs immediately, keeping in mind the economic interests of businesses in our city and the fact that we cannot afford another lockdown.
All the best, Sabeeha el-Yacoub – (Read Again, proprietor)









Email #3

Dear Pandemic Response Busybodies,
I fear that you and your office are going to use this new pandemic as yet another excuse for government overreach into citizens’ lives. This last pandemic was just a typical example of what governments do when given a little too much power.
Please do not use this disaster as another opportunity for oppressive lockdowns and government control of our lives.

Email #4





From: kyle.wilson@mail.com  To: pandemic_response@Inverkeld.co.uk  Cc:  Subject: Devastating Pandemic  Date: 29 January 2025 12:09 
Dear Pandemic Response Committee,
I have just learned that my my nana’s best friend has passed away due to the new pandemic in Inverkeld. You cannot begin to imagine the grief that we are feeling.
This is especially terrible coming hard on the heels of all of our losses due to COVID-19.
I really wish that our government had better learned its lessons from the COVID-19 pandemic and could have prevented this terrible tragedy.
Yours sincerely, Kyle Wilson





News/Blog Posts
Your committee has also been monitoring news and published blog posts about the pandemic in Inverkeld, in order to better gauge public opinion. A representative sample of these is shown below.






News/blog post #1





Informed Actions: The Role of Data in Pandemic Response
An update on the outbreak in Inverkeld
Published in: Public Health and Peer Review By: Kyle Wilson Date: 29 January 2025
As the pandemic continues to unfold in Inverkeld, public health experts emphasize the importance of data-driven decisions to protect communities and save lives. By analyzing data from various sources, including infection rates, health officials can implement targeted measures to curb the spread of the disease.
Dr. Nadiyya Salaz, a leading infectious disease specialist, explains, “Our approach relies on robust data analysis to identify hotspots and allocate resources efficiently. By understanding the patterns of transmission, we will be able to introduce interventions that are both successful and minimally disruptive.”
Recent data has shown that areas with higher vaccination rates are experiencing significantly lower infection rates and hospitalizations. “Vaccination will be our most powerful tool,” says Salaz. “The data clearly confirms for similar outbreaks that there is a correlation between implementation of public health measures and reduced severity of the disease.”
These public health measures, such as quarantine measures, will be crucial while new vaccines or treatments are developed and rolled out. “These interventions are based on solid evidence,” notes Salaz. “They help to protect the vulnerable populations who might not yet be vaccinated or might have underlying health conditions.”
The public is encouraged to stay informed through reliable sources and adhere to guidelines issued by health authorities. “Trust in science and data is paramount,” concludes Salaz. “Together, we can navigate through this pandemic by making informed, sensible decisions.”
Credits: Kyle Wilson has been writing for the Public Health and Peer Review for the past 4 years, with a primary focus on epidemiology. Kyle Wilson interviewed Nadiyya Salaz on Tuesday, 28/01/2025.









News/blog post #2





The Pandemic Apocalypse: Are We on the Brink of Collapse? –Badraan al-Ghani, senior health correspondent for The Journal 30 January 2025
The world is descending into chaos as a new pandemic hits Inverkeld. This unprecedented pandemic is coming right after COVID-19 and monkey pox, amongst other diseases, have already taken an outrageous toll on the citizens of Inverkeld and nearby cities. It seems like the situation is spiraling out of control. With infection rates skyrocketing and new, more deadly variants emerging, experts warn that we could be facing the end times.
Hospitals are soon going to be overwhelmed, unable to cope with the sheer volume of critically ill patients. “We’ve never seen anything like this,” says Dr. Dohn, a emergency room physician at the Queen Rose. “After years and years of harsh cuts to the NHS, we’re in a terrible state. We’re running out of PPE,, beds, and even basic medical supplies. It’s a nightmare scenario.”
The death toll is climbing at an alarming rate, with terrible projections suggesting that the virus could wipe out entire communities. “We’re losing this battle,” states Dr. Dohn. “Without immediate and drastic action, the situation will only get more hopeless.” It is by no means clear that Inverkeld will be able to contain the pandemic.
Panic is spreading as quickly as the virus itself. People are stocking up on canned foods,, hoarding supplies, and fearing the worst. “I’ve never been so scared in my life as I was during the COVID lockdowns,” says Maya Heath, a mother of two. “It brings it all back. We don’t know what tomorrow will bring. Every day is a struggle for survival.”
The future looks bleak, with no end in sight. “This is just the beginning,” warns Dr. Dohn. “The pathogen is mutating, making it harder to control. We’ll be in for a long, dark spring.” Other experts have noted that due to global warming, pandemics are likely to occur more frequently and be more severe in a warming world.
As fear and uncertainty grip the world, one thing is clear: we must prepare for the worst. The pandemic apocalypse is upon us, and there is no turning back.









News/blog post #3





Exposing the Vaccine Lie: What They’re Not Telling You - Dylan Spangler - 31 January 2025 Published in: Freedom Health Blog
Wake up, people! There’s a new “pandemic” in Inverkeld. This one is supposedly due to something called Legionella pneumophila (according to something the “experts” call “germ theory” and which has been proven to be another Big Fat Lie.)
The so-called “scamdemic” is nothing but a ploy by the government and Big Pharma to control your lives and make billions off their poisonous vaccines. Don’t be fooled by their lies tactics!
First off, the virus is a complete fabrication. The numbers are inflated to scare you into compliance. Have you noticed how quickly they came up with new “COVID” “variants” every time people started questioning their narrative? The new pandemic in Inverkeld is just more of the same. It’s all a big lie to keep you in fear and under control.
And the vaccines? Don’t even get me started. They’re filled with harmful chemicals and rushed ingredients that have never been tested long-term. What even is this SO-CALLED ribonucleic acid? Why do you think they’re pushing so hard to get everyone jabbed? It’s not about your health, it’s about making money and keeping you obedient.
People who’ve taken the vaccine are reporting all kinds of side effects, but the media won’t tell you that. They’re in on it too! Censorship is rampant, and anyone who dares to speak the truth is silenced. Ask yourself why they’re so desperate to shut down any dissenting voices.
Herbal remedies is the way to go. Boost your immune system with vitamins, a healthy diet, and regular exercise. Don’t let them inject you with their toxic concoctions. Do your own research and think for yourself. The truth is out there if you look beyond the mainstream propaganda.
Don’t be a sheep. Stand up for your rights and say no to the vaccine scam. Your health and freedom depend on it!
[Keep watching this space - we’ll keep you informed on all the latest health news and help keep you healthy! Coming up next week - challenging the narrative on herd immunity!]

There are currently 462 patients in the Queen Rose (with confirmed Legionellosis, or symptoms consistent with Legionellosis
There are currently 16 patients currently in the ICU with confirmed Legionellosis

Epidemiological Data
A team of scientists working together have cultured Legionella pneumophila from a number of patient sputum samples; isolated genomic DNA from these strains; sequenced this genomic DNA using an Illumina MiSeq platform; assembled the short paired-end reads; and compared these assemblies to the extant Legionella pneumophila sequences available in the NCBI databases. Epidemic Calculator

Hospital Info
The Queen Rose, built in 2010, is the main hospital in Inverkeld.
The Queen Rose has units specialising in nephrology, neurology, dermatology, endocrinology and an eye clinic.

A&E Statistics

While progress has been made, we acknowledge that certain goals remain unmet. We are actively working to address these challenges and enhance patient care.
Key Performance Targets:

Waiting time for an ambulance (category 2 event) should be no more than 18 minutes
95% or more of all patients waiting in A&E should be seen in less than 4 hours

title: 3  Group A Hospital Dashboard
text:
Infection Control Metrics

The Queen Rose hospital strives to meet stringent targets for infection control and antibiotic stewardship to ensure patient safety and combat antimicrobial resistance. Infection control protocols are critical in maintaining high standards of hygiene and patient care. Similarly, antibiotic stewardship programs are essential for optimizing the use of antimicrobials, thereby reducing the risk of resistance and ensuring effective treatments for future generations.

There were the same number of hospital-acquired MRSA infections in 2024 and 2025.
There were 4 fewer hospital-acquired Clostridiodes difficile infections in 2025 than there were in 2024.
There were 2 fewer hospital-acquired Candida auris infections in 2025 than there were in 2024.







Hospital-acquired MRSA cases (trend)


2








Hospital-acquired C. difficile cases (trend)


4








Hospital-acquired Candida auris cases (trend)


7








Antibiotic prescriptions judged appropriate (%)


90%








Antibiotic de-escalation rate (%)


20%








Prevalence of MDR-resistant organisms (%)


51%

title: 3  Group A Hospital Dashboard
text:
Community Health Data

The Queen Rose monitors the prevalence of COVID-19 and other viruses in the community to ensure they are prepared for potential surges in patient admissions, enabling them to allocate resources and staff efficiently. By tracking these trends, the hospital can implement timely public health interventions and provide accurate information to the community to mitigate the spread of infections. Additionally, continuous monitoring helps in identifying emerging outbreaks early, allowing for a rapid response that minimizes the impact on public health and healthcare services.

There were 41 more COVID-19 cases this week than in the previous week.
We are seeing an increase in infections caused by other respiratory viruses (e.g., influenza, adenovirus, rhinovirus, RSV).







COVID-19 cases (weekly)

title: 4  Group A - References
text:
Tip



The following list of references is provided as a starting place for you to begin exploring various aspects of Legionella pneumophila biology, diagnostics, epidemiology, and treatment. However, this is by no means an exhaustive list: you should further explore the relevant peer-reviewed literature independently.



Selected Legionella pneumophila Public Health LiteratureSelected Legionella pneumophila Diagnostics and TreatmentSelected Legionella pneumophila Epidemiology Literature



Guidelines on the management of Legionella cases, incidents,outbreaks and clusters in the community: Health Protection Network Scottish Guidance
Cluster of Legionella longbeachae cases in Scotland in September/October 2013: Report from a national Incident Management Team
CDC Fact Sheet - Legionnaires’ Disease: Use water management programs in buildings to help prevent outbreaks
CDC Legionella Communications Resources
Legionnaires’ disease outbreak investigation toolbox: Developing Communications
Legionella awareness campaign highlights deadly Legionella hotspots
Hyland, J M et al. “Outbreak of Legionnaires’ disease in West Fife: review of environmental guidelines needed.” Public health vol. 122,1 (2008): 79-83.
Nisar, Muhammad Atif et al. “Legionella pneumophila and Protozoan Hosts: Implications for the Control of Hospital and Potable Water Systems.” Pathogens (Basel, Switzerland) vol. 9,4 286. 15 Apr. 2020

title: 6  Hospital Data
text:
6.4 Row 3, a&e stats

As part of the Queen Rose’s ongoing commitment to excellence, the hospital diligently monitors key performance indicators and strives to meet established targets. While progress has been made, we acknowledge that certain goals remain unmet. We are actively working to address these challenges and enhance patient care.
Key Performance Targets:

Waiting time for an ambulance (category 2 event) should be no more than 18 minutes
95% or more of all patients waiting in A&E should be seen in less than 4 hours
85% of all patients waiting for cancer treatment should be seen within 62 days

title: 6  Hospital Data
text:
6.7 Row 5, header

The Queen Rose hospital strives to meet stringent targets for infection control and antibiotic stewardship to ensure patient safety and combat antimicrobial resistance. Infection control protocols are critical in maintaining high standards of hygiene and patient care. Similarly, antibiotic stewardship programs are essential for optimizing the use of antimicrobials, thereby reducing the risk of resistance and ensuring effective treatments for future generations.

There were 4 more hospital-acquired MRSA infections in 2025 than there were in 2024.
There were 4 fewer hospital-acquired Clostridiodes difficile infections in 2025 than there were in 2024.
There were 2 more hospital-acquired Candida auris infections in 2025 than there were in 2024.

title: 6  Hospital Data
text:
6.10 Row 8a, header

The Queen Rose monitors the prevalence of COVID-19 and other viruses in the community to ensure they are prepared for potential surges in patient admissions, enabling them to allocate resources and staff efficiently. By tracking these trends, the hospital can implement timely public health interventions and provide accurate information to the community to mitigate the spread of infections. Additionally, continuous monitoring helps in identifying emerging outbreaks early, allowing for a rapid response that minimizes the impact on public health and healthcare services.

There were 39 fewer COVID-19 cases this week than in the previous week.
We are seeing an increase in infections caused by other respiratory viruses (e.g., influenza, adenovirus, rhinovirus, RSV).
